thread.title: David Shore, Caroline Cavin help CAK sweep region golf titles
thread.title_full: David Shore, Caroline Cavin help CAK sweep region golf titles - PrepXtra Story

author: Mike Blackerby
title: David Shore, Caroline Cavin help CAK sweep region golf titles
text:
SEVIERVILLE — Just moments after signing his winning scorecard at the Region 2-A/AA golf tournament on Thursday, Davis Shore of Christian Academy of Knoxville was back on the practice tee.
All by himself, in the rain.
“That’s the difference,” CAK boys coach Hank Fennell said. “He’s on the range and he just shot a 3-under. I’ve never seen anybody with a work ethic like him.”
Shore, a consensus top-five golfer in the national and world junior rankings, fired a 69 Thursday on the River Course at windy, rain-swept Sevierville Golf Club to successfully defend his region title.
Photo gallery: Scenes from the tournament Shore and the Warriors carded a team score of 301 to earn a return trip to the state tournament Oct. 13-14 at WillowBrook Golf Club in Manchester.
Freshman Cade Russell recorded a 72 while juniors Tyler Young and Preston Burleson shot 79 and 81, respectively, as CAK repeated as region champ.
Catholic (311) was second and Alcoa (329) third.
The first-place team and the top four individual finishers not on the winning team advanced to the state tournament.
“It was a good day for us,” said Fennell, whose boys finished second in the state a year ago. “Our goal was to try and break 300, and we shot 301, which is still pretty solid in these conditions with the rain and the wind.
“Davis wasn’t very happy with his 69, which is a barometer that shows you how hard the course was playing in these conditions.”
Shore, who was medalist last year at the state tournament, said the weather definitely impacted the scoring.
“It was windy, a little chilly and the course was really wet,” the junior said. “It was tough because of that, and I was playing conservative.”
Shore said a team state championship has been a goal all season. The Warriors fell just short a year ago, finishing second by three strokes to Christ Presbyterian Academy.
CAK last won a boys state golf championship in 2010.
“I really hope the team can win state this year,” Shore said. “I think we have a great chance.”
Fennell said the Warriors head to state on a high note after Thursday’s showing.
“Davis is on top of his game, and the weather even makes Cade’s 72 even more impressive. He was really solid today,” he said. “We’re looking forward to getting back to state. We were so close last year. We’re hungry for another opportunity.”
Other individuals advancing to state play are Grace Christian’s Luke Scealf (74), Kingston’s Brady Davis (75), Catholic’s Eli Cox (76) and Carter’s Jake Mynatt (76).
CAK made it a clean sweep as the Lady Warriors took both team and individual honors.
CAK junior Caroline Cavin had a 1-over-par 71 on the Highlands Course to medal.
Cavin, who had five birdies and six bogeys, said a disappointing showing in the district tournament (83) was just the inspiration she needed.
CAK girls coach Donnie Cooper said Cavin bounced back strong.
“She really hit it well and executed off the tee today,” Cooper said.
CAK’s Emma Wasson overcame a triple bogey on the first hole to finish with a 77 as the Lady Warriors won with a team score of 148.
Union County (181) was second and Oneida (189) third.
Other individuals to qualify for state were Kaitlyn Sneed (75) of Meigs County, Savannah Szozda (77) of Kingston, Emily Hutson (85) of Oneida and Kayla Williams (90) of Union County.
Mike Blackerby is a freelance contributor.
